text: a judge in the united states has blocked
a near-total ban on abortion in the
state of texas following a challenge by
the biden administration
judge robert pittman issued a temporary
injunction saying his court wouldn't
sanction one more day of what he
described as the offensive deprivation
of an important right
our reporter courtney bembridge told me
more about the law
it prohibited abortion
any time after six weeks now it applied
in cases of rape and incest too which
made it instantly controversial and the
biden administration launched a
challenge against that law a judge has
now considered that challenge and that's
why he stepped in and put the temporary
halt some very strong words from judge
pittman just tell us more about what he
said
yes i'm going to actually bring up his
words so that we can read them together
he said this court will not sanction one
more day of this offensive deprivation
of such an important right and he also
called out texas officials for crafting
what he said was an unprecedented and
aggressive scheme now that's because the
way this law operates is a little bit
different to previous laws it put the
onus on private citizens to launch
lawsuits against people accused of
helping someone uh go through with the
termination now they could get payments
back of about 10 000 u.s dollars and
critics say that amounted to a bounty so
rather than law enforcement uh trying to
prohibit people getting an abortion
private citizens were able to sue anyone
who helped them so that's where this law
differed and that's why early challenges
haven't been successful so
it's interesting now that the court has
stepped in to put a temporary ban while
all this comes out in the court but of
course it's all very interesting in the
context of roe versus wade which since
1973 has allowed women in the u.s to get
an abortion now jen saki the u.s white
house
press secretary mentioned roe versus way
today and we can have a look at what
else she said uh after this she said the
fight has only just begun both in texas
and in many states across this country
where women's rights are currently under
attack but she did say that today's
ruling or overnight's ruling was an
important step forward in terms of
restoring constitutional rights for
women in texas now as you mentioned this
is just a temporary block on this new
law what happens next well this will no
doubt end up before this the supreme
court
an appeal is very likely to be lodged
but in the meantime abortion providers
in texas are saying they are preparing
to open their doors once again so women
can access services there but there are
other doctors that have raised concerns
that they might be personally liable
that they could be
still vulnerable to private suits and
they are maybe a little more cautious
about whether they should be operating
as normal so it's a wait and see at this
stage to see how that pans out but
certainly the temporary ban is in place
for now which means that abortion is
legal
courtney benbridge
